Cucumber Features

Expand All

Collapse All

Feature: Delayed announcement

Background

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Given /^I use announce with text "(.*)"$/ do |ann| x=1
  announce(ann)
end

Given /^I use multiple announces$/ do x=1
  announce("Multiple")
  announce(["Announce","Me"])
end

Given /^I use announcement (.+) in line (.+) (?:with result (.+))$/ do |ann, line, result| x=1
  announce("Last announcement") if line == "3"
  announce("Line: #{line}: #{ann}")
  fail if result =~ /fail/i
end

Given /^I use announce and step fails$/ do x=1
  announce("Announce with fail")
  fail
end

Given /^this step works$/ do x=1
end

Given /^I announce the world$/ do x=1
  announce_world
end
  3. And a file named "features/f.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: F

  Scenario: S
    Given I use announce with text "Ann"
    And this step works

  Scenario: S2
    Given I use multiple announces
    And this step works

  Scenario Outline: S3
    Given I use announcement  in line 

    Examples:
      | line | ann |
      | 1 | anno1 |
      | 2 | anno2 |
      | 3 | anno3 |

  Scenario: S4
    Given I use announce and step fails
    And this step works

  Scenario Outline: s5
    Given I use announcement  in line  with result 

    Examples:
      | line | ann | result |
      | 1 | anno1 | fail |
      | 2 | anno2 | pass |
  4. And a file named "features/announce_world.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: announce_world
  Scenario: announce_world
    Given I announce the world

Scenario: Delayed announcements feature

  1. When I run cucumber --format pretty features/f.feature
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  2. Then STDERR should be empty
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:131
  3. And the output should contain
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:79
    Feature: F

  Scenario: S                            # features/f.feature:3
    Given I use announce with text "Ann" # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:1
      Ann
    And this step works                  # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:21

  Scenario: S2                     # features/f.feature:7
    Given I use multiple announces # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:5
      Multiple
      Announce
      Me
    And this step works            # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:21

  Scenario Outline: S3                            # features/f.feature:11
    Given I use announcement  in line  # features/f.feature:12

    Examples: 
      | line | ann   |
      | 1    | anno1 |
      | 2    | anno2 |
      | 3    | anno3 |

  Scenario: S4                          # features/f.feature:20
    Given I use announce and step fails # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:16
      Announce with fail
       (RuntimeError)
      ./features/step_definitions/steps.rb:18:in `/^I use announce and step fails$/'
      features/f.feature:21:in `Given I use announce and step fails'
    And this step works                 # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:21

  Scenario Outline: s5                                                 # features/f.feature:24
    Given I use announcement  in line  with result  # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:10

    Examples: 
      | line | ann   | result |
      | 1    | anno1 | fail   |  Line: 1: anno1
       (RuntimeError)
      ./features/step_definitions/steps.rb:13:in `/^I use announcement (.+) in line (.+) (?:with result (.+))$/'
      features/f.feature:25:in `Given I use announcement  in line  with result '
      | 2    | anno2 | pass   |  Line: 2: anno2

Scenario: Non-delayed announcements feature (progress formatter)

  1. When I run cucumber --format progress features/f.feature
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  2. Then the output should contain
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:79
    Ann
..
Multiple

Announce
Me
..-UUUUUU
Announce with fail
F--
Line: 1: anno1
FFF
Line: 2: anno2
...
@rspec2

Scenario: announce world

  1. When I run cucumber --format progress features/announce_world.feature
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  2. Then the output should contain
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:79
    WORLD:
  Object

  RSpec::Matchers
  Cucumber::RbSupport::RbWorld

Feature: List step defs as json

In order to build tools on top of Cucumber
As a tool developer
I want to be able to query a features directory for all the step definitions it contains

Background

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8

Scenario: Two Ruby step definitions, in the same file

  1. Given a file named "features/step_definitions/foo_steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Given(/foo/i) {}
Given(/b.r/xm) {}
  2. When I run the following Ruby code:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:60
    require 'cucumber'
puts Cucumber::StepDefinitions.new.to_json
  3. Then it should pass
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:64
  4. And the output should contain the following JSON:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:164
    [
  {"source": "foo", "flags": "i"},
  {"source": "b.r", "flags": "mx"}
]

Scenario: Non-default directory structure

  1. Given a file named "my_weird/place/foo_steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Given(/foo/) {}
Given(/b.r/x) {}
  2. When I run the following Ruby code:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:60
    require 'cucumber'
puts Cucumber::StepDefinitions.new(:autoload_code_paths => ['my_weird']).to_json
  3. Then it should pass
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:64
  4. And the output should contain the following JSON:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:164
    [
  {"source": "foo", "flags": ""},
  {"source": "b.r", "flags": "x"}
]

Feature: Run Cli::Main with existing Runtime


This is the API that Spork uses. It creates an existing runtime then
calls load_programming_language('rb') on it to load the RbDsl.
When the process forks, Spork them passes the runtime to Cli::Main to
run it.

Background

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8

Scenario: Run a single feature

  1. Given a file named "features/step_definitions/success.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Given(/pass/) {}
  2. Given a file named "features/success.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: 
  Scenario: 
    Given I pass
  3. When I run the following Ruby code:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:60
    require 'cucumber'
runtime = Cucumber::Runtime.new
runtime.load_programming_language('rb')
Cucumber::Cli::Main.new([]).execute!(runtime)
  4. Then it should pass
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:64
  5. And the output should contain:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:79
    Given I pass

Feature: Around hooks

In order to support transactional scenarios for database libraries
that provide only a block syntax for transactions, Cucumber should
permit definition of Around hooks.

Scenario: A single Around hook

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Then /^the hook is called$/ do
  $hook_called.should == true
end
  3. And a file named "features/support/hooks.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Around do |scenario, block|
  $hook_called = true
  block.call
end
  4. And a file named "features/f.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: Around hooks
  Scenario: using hook
    Then the hook is called
  5. When I run cucumber features/f.feature
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  6. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Around hooks

  Scenario: using hook      # features/f.feature:2
    Then the hook is called # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:1

1 scenario (1 passed)
1 step (1 passed)

Scenario: Multiple Around hooks

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Then /^the hooks are called in the correct order$/ do
  $hooks_called.should == ['A', 'B', 'C']
end
  3. And a file named "features/support/hooks.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Around do |scenario, block|
  $hooks_called ||= []
  $hooks_called << 'A'
  block.call
end

Around do |scenario, block|
  $hooks_called ||= []
  $hooks_called << 'B'
  block.call
end

Around do |scenario, block|
  $hooks_called ||= []
  $hooks_called << 'C'
  block.call
end
  4. And a file named "features/f.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: Around hooks
  Scenario: using multiple hooks
    Then the hooks are called in the correct order
  5. When I run cucumber features/f.feature
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  6. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Around hooks

  Scenario: using multiple hooks                   # features/f.feature:2
    Then the hooks are called in the correct order # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:1

1 scenario (1 passed)
1 step (1 passed)

Scenario: Mixing Around, Before, and After hooks

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Then /^the Around hook is called around Before and After hooks$/ do
  $hooks_called.should == ['Around', 'Before']
end
  3. And a file named "features/support/hooks.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Around do |scenario, block|
  $hooks_called ||= []
  $hooks_called << 'Around'
  block.call
  $hooks_called << 'Around'
  $hooks_called.should == ['Around', 'Before', 'After', 'Around']
end

Before do |scenario|
  $hooks_called ||= []
  $hooks_called << 'Before'
end

After do |scenario|
  $hooks_called ||= []
  $hooks_called << 'After'
  $hooks_called.should == ['Around', 'Before', 'After']
end
  4. And a file named "features/f.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: Around hooks
  Scenario: Mixing Around, Before, and After hooks
    Then the Around hook is called around Before and After hooks
  5. When I run cucumber features/f.feature
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  6. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Around hooks

  Scenario: Mixing Around, Before, and After hooks               # features/f.feature:2
    Then the Around hook is called around Before and After hooks # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:1

1 scenario (1 passed)
1 step (1 passed)

Scenario: Around hooks with tags

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Then /^the Around hooks with matching tags are called$/ do
  $hooks_called.should == ['one', 'one or two']
end
  3. And a file named "features/support/hooks.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Around('@one') do |scenario, block|
  $hooks_called ||= []
  $hooks_called << 'one'
  block.call
end

Around('@one,@two') do |scenario, block|
  $hooks_called ||= []
  $hooks_called << 'one or two'
  block.call
end

Around('@one', '@two') do |scenario, block|
  $hooks_called ||= []
  $hooks_called << 'one and two'
  block.call
end

Around('@two') do |scenario, block|
  $hooks_called ||= []
  $hooks_called << 'two'
  block.call
end
  4. And a file named "features/f.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: Around hooks
  @one
  Scenario: Around hooks with tags
    Then the Around hooks with matching tags are called
  5. When I run cucumber -q -t @one features/f.feature
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  6. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Around hooks

  @one
  Scenario: Around hooks with tags
    Then the Around hooks with matching tags are called

1 scenario (1 passed)
1 step (1 passed)

Scenario: Around hooks with scenario outlines

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Then /^the hook is called$/ do
  $hook_called.should == true
end
  3. And a file named "features/support/hooks.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Around do |scenario, block|
  $hook_called = true
  block.call
end
  4. And a file named "features/f.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: Around hooks with scenario outlines
  Scenario Outline: using hook
    Then the hook is called

    Examples:
      | Number |
      | one    |
      | two    |
  5. When I run cucumber features/f.feature
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  6. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Around hooks with scenario outlines

  Scenario Outline: using hook # features/f.feature:2
    Then the hook is called    # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:1

    Examples: 
      | Number |
      | one    |
      | two    |

2 scenarios (2 passed)
2 steps (2 passed)

Feature: backgrounds

In order to provide a context to my scenarios within a feature
As a feature editor
I want to write a background section in my features.

Scenario: run a specific scenario with a background

  1. When I run cucumber -q features/background/passing_background.feature:9 --require features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  2. Then STDERR should be empty
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:131
  3. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Passing background sample

  Background: 
    Given '10' cukes

  Scenario: another passing background
    Then I should have '10' cukes

1 scenario (1 passed)
2 steps (2 passed)

Scenario: run a feature with a background that passes

  1. When I run cucumber -q features/background/passing_background.feature --require features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  2. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Passing background sample

  Background: 
    Given '10' cukes

  Scenario: passing background
    Then I should have '10' cukes

  Scenario: another passing background
    Then I should have '10' cukes

2 scenarios (2 passed)
4 steps (4 passed)

Scenario: run a feature with scenario outlines that has a background that passes

  1. When I run cucumber -q features/background/scenario_outline_passing_background.feature --require features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  2. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Passing background with scenario outlines sample

  Background: 
    Given '10' cukes

  Scenario Outline: passing background
    Then I should have '' cukes

    Examples: 
      | count |
      | 10    |

  Scenario Outline: another passing background
    Then I should have '' cukes

    Examples: 
      | count |
      | 10    |

2 scenarios (2 passed)
4 steps (4 passed)

Scenario: run a feature with scenario outlines that has a background that passes

  1. When I run cucumber -q features/background/background_tagged_before_on_outline.feature --require features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  2. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    @background_tagged_before_on_outline
Feature: Background tagged Before on Outline

  Background: 
    Given passing without a table

  Scenario Outline: passing background
    Then I should have '' cukes

    Examples: 
      | count |
      | 888   |

1 scenario (1 passed)
2 steps (2 passed)

Scenario: run a feature with a background that fails

  1. When I run cucumber -q features/background/failing_background.feature --require features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  2. Then it should fail with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    @after_file
Feature: Failing background sample

  Background: 
    Given failing without a table
      FAIL (RuntimeError)
      ./features/step_definitions/sample_steps.rb:2:in `flunker'
      ./features/step_definitions/sample_steps.rb:16:in `/^failing without a table$/'
      features/background/failing_background.feature:5:in `Given failing without a table'
    And '10' cukes

  Scenario: failing background
    Then I should have '10' cukes

  Scenario: another failing background
    Then I should have '10' cukes

Failing Scenarios:
cucumber features/background/failing_background.feature:8 # Scenario: failing background

2 scenarios (1 failed, 1 skipped)
6 steps (1 failed, 5 skipped)
  3. And "fixtures/self_test/tmp/after.txt" should exist
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:135

Scenario: run a feature with scenario outlines that has a background that fails

  1. When I run cucumber -q features/background/scenario_outline_failing_background.feature --require features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  2. Then it should fail with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Failing background with scenario outlines sample

  Background: 
    Given failing without a table
      FAIL (RuntimeError)
      ./features/step_definitions/sample_steps.rb:2:in `flunker'
      ./features/step_definitions/sample_steps.rb:16:in `/^failing without a table$/'
      features/background/scenario_outline_failing_background.feature:4:in `Given failing without a table'

  Scenario Outline: failing background
    Then I should have '' cukes

    Examples: 
      | count |
      | 10    |

  Scenario Outline: another failing background
    Then I should have '' cukes

    Examples: 
      | count |
      | 10    |

Failing Scenarios:
cucumber features/background/scenario_outline_failing_background.feature:6 # Scenario: failing background

2 scenarios (1 failed, 1 skipped)
4 steps (1 failed, 3 skipped)

Scenario: run a feature with a background that is pending

  1. When I run cucumber -q features/background/pending_background.feature --require features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  2. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Pending background sample

  Background: 
    Given pending

  Scenario: pending background
    Then I should have '10' cukes

  Scenario: another pending background
    Then I should have '10' cukes

2 scenarios (2 undefined)
4 steps (2 skipped, 2 undefined)

Scenario: background passes with first scenario but fails with second

  1. When I run cucumber -q features/background/failing_background_after_success.feature --require features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  2. Then it should fail with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Failing background after previously successful background sample

  Background: 
    Given passing without a table
    And '10' global cukes

  Scenario: passing background
    Then I should have '10' global cukes

  Scenario: failing background
    And '10' global cukes
      FAIL (RuntimeError)
      ./features/step_definitions/sample_steps.rb:2:in `flunker'
      ./features/step_definitions/sample_steps.rb:37:in `/^'(.+)' global cukes$/'
      features/background/failing_background_after_success.feature:5:in `And '10' global cukes'
    Then I should have '10' global cukes

Failing Scenarios:
cucumber features/background/failing_background_after_success.feature:10 # Scenario: failing background

2 scenarios (1 failed, 1 passed)
6 steps (1 failed, 1 skipped, 4 passed)

Scenario: background with multline args

  1. When I run cucumber -q features/background/multiline_args_background.feature --require features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  2. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Passing background with multiline args

  Background: 
    Given table
      | a | b |
      | c | d |
    And multiline string
      """
        I'm a cucumber and I'm okay. 
        I sleep all night and I test all day
      """

  Scenario: passing background
    Then the table should be
      | a | b |
      | c | d |
    Then the multiline string should be
      """
        I'm a cucumber and I'm okay. 
        I sleep all night and I test all day
      """

  Scenario: another passing background
    Then the table should be
      | a | b |
      | c | d |
    Then the multiline string should be
      """
        I'm a cucumber and I'm okay. 
        I sleep all night and I test all day
      """

2 scenarios (2 passed)
8 steps (8 passed)

Scenario: background with name

  1. When I run cucumber -q features/background/background_with_name.feature --require features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  2. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: background with name

  Background: I'm a background and I'm ok
    Given '10' cukes

  Scenario: example
    Then I should have '10' cukes

1 scenario (1 passed)
2 steps (2 passed)

Scenario: https://rspec.lighthouseapp.com/projects/16211/tickets/329

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/only_background_and_hooks.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: woo yeah

  Background:
    Given whatever
  3. And a file named "features/only_background_and_hooks_steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    begin require 'rspec/expectations'; rescue LoadError; require 'spec/expectations'; end

Before do
  $before = true
end

After do
  $after = true
end

Given(/^whatever$/) { $before.should == true; $step = true }

at_exit do
  $before.should == true
  $step.should == true
  $after.should == true
end
  4. When I run cucumber features/only_background_and_hooks.feature
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  5. Then it should pass
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:64
  6. And the output should be
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:87
    Feature: woo yeah

  Background:      # features/only_background_and_hooks.feature:3
    Given whatever # features/only_background_and_hooks_steps.rb:11

0 scenarios
1 step (1 passed)
  7. And STDERR should be empty
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:131

Feature: https://rspec.lighthouseapp.com/projects/16211/tickets/371

Scenario: Before runs once

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/f.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: F
  Scenario: S
    Given G
  3. And a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Before do
  puts "B"
end
Given /G/ do
  puts "G"
end
  4. When I run cucumber -q --format pretty --format progress --out progress.txt features/f.feature
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  5. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: F

  Scenario: S
B
G
    Given G

1 scenario (1 passed)
1 step (1 passed)

Feature: https://rspec.lighthouseapp.com/projects/16211/tickets/464

Scenario: Limiting with tags which do not exist in the features

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/f.feature" with:

Feature: http://rspec.lighthouseapp.com/projects/16211/tickets/600-inconsistent-order-of-execution-background-and-before-in-070beta2

Scenario: Background executed twice when scenario follows scenario outline

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/t.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: test
  Background: 
    Given I am in the background

  Scenario Outline: test 1
    Given I am a step

    Examples:
      | a |
      | 1 |

  Scenario: test 2
  3. And a file named "features/step_definitions/t_steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Given "I am in the background" do
  puts "Within background"
end

Given "I am a step" do
  # no-op
end
  4. And a file named "features/support/env.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    module TestWorld
  def before_scenario
    puts "Before scenario"
  end

  def after_scenario
    puts "After scenario"
  end
end

World(TestWorld)

Before do
  before_scenario
end

After do
  after_scenario
end
  5. When I run cucumber -f progress features/t.feature
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  6. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Before scenario
Within background
.--After scenario
Before scenario
Within background
.After scenario


2 scenarios (2 passed)
3 steps (3 passed)

Feature: http://gist.github.com/221223

In order to make it easier to extract several steps from
a feature file to a step definition I want to be able to
copy and paste.

Background

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/f.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: Test

  Scenario: Multiline string
    Given a multiline string:
       """
       hello
       world
       """

  Scenario: Call a multiline string
    Given I call a multiline string with MAMA

  Scenario: Call a table
    Given I call a table with MAMA

  Scenario: Call a multiline string using keyword
    Given I use keyword to call a multiline string with BANG
  3. And a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    And /^a multiline string:$/ do |s| x=1
  raise "I got multiline:\n#{s}"
end

Given /^a table:$/ do |t| x=1
  raise "I got table:\n#{t.raw.inspect}"
end

Given /^I call a multiline string with (.*)$/ do |s| x=1
  steps %Q{
    And a multiline string:
      """
      hello
      #{s}
      """
  }
end

Given /^I use keyword to call a multiline string with (.*)$/ do |s| x=1
  Given 'a multiline string:', "Hello\n#{s}"
end

Given /^I call a table with (.*)$/ do |s| x=1
  steps %Q{
    Given a table:
      |a|b|
      |c|#{s}|
  }
end

Scenario: Multiline string

  1. When I run cucumber features/f.feature:3
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  2. Then STDERR should be empty
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:131
  3. And it should fail with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Test

  Scenario: Multiline string  # features/f.feature:3

      hello
      world
      """
      I got multiline:
      hello
      world (RuntimeError)
      ./features/step_definitions/steps.rb:2:in `/^a multiline string:$/'

74Then /^it should (fail|pass) with$/ do |success, output|
75  combined_output.should =~ Regexp.compile(Regexp.escape(output))
76  Then("it should #{success}")
77end

Scenario: my own formatter

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/f.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: I'll use my own
  because I'm worth it
  Scenario: just print me
    Given this step works
  3. And a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Given /^this step works$/ do
end
  4. And a file named "features/support/ze/formator.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    module Ze
  class Formator
    def initialize(step_mother, io, options)
      @step_mother = step_mother
      @io = io
    end

    def before_feature(feature)
      @io.puts feature.short_name.upcase
    end

    def scenario_name(keyword, name, file_colon_line, source_indent)
      @io.puts "  #{name.upcase}"
    end
  end
end
  5. When I run cucumber features/f.feature --format Ze::Formator
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  6. Then STDERR should be empty
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:131
  7. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    I'LL USE MY OWN
  JUST PRINT ME

Scenario: Legacy pre-0.7.0 formatter

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/f.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: We like old cukes
  Scenario Outline: just print me
    Given this step works

    Examples: print me too
      |foo|
      |bar|
  3. And a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Given /^this step works$/ do
end
  4. And a file named "features/support/legacy/formator.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    module Legacy
  class Formator
    def initialize(step_mother, io, options)
      @io = io
    end

    def feature_name(name)
      @io.puts name
    end

    def scenario_name(keyword, name, file_colon_line, source_indent)
      @io.puts "#{keyword} #{name}"
    end

    def examples_name(keyword, name)
      @io.puts "#{keyword} #{name}"
    end
  end
end
  5. When I run cucumber features/f.feature --format Legacy::Formator
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  6. Then STDERR should be
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:127
    Legacy::Formator is using a deprecated formatter API. Starting with Cucumber 0.7.0 the signatures
that have changed are:
  feature_name(keyword, name)  # Two arguments. The keyword argument will not contain a colon.
  scenario_name(keyword, name, file_colon_line, source_indent)  # The keyword argument will not contain a colon.
  examples_name(keyword, name)  # The keyword argument will not contain a colon.
  7. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: We like old cukes
Scenario Outline: just print me
Examples: print me too

Feature: Print snippets

In order to make it easier to implement step definitions
Developers should get a scaffolding for undefined step definitions

Scenario: Cucumber doesn't know what language, and defaults to Ruby

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/x.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: X
  Scenario: Y
    Given Z
    Given Q
  3. When I run cucumber features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  4. Then STDERR should be empty
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:131
  5. And it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: X

  Scenario: Y # features/x.feature:2
    Given Z   # features/x.feature:3
    Given Q   # features/x.feature:4

1 scenario (1 undefined)
2 steps (2 undefined)

You can implement step definitions for undefined steps with these snippets:

Given /^Z$/ do
  pending # express the regexp above with the code you wish you had
end

Given /^Q$/ do
  pending # express the regexp above with the code you wish you had
end

If you want snippets in a different programming language, just make sure a file
with the appropriate file extension exists where cucumber looks for step definitions.

Feature: Cucumber command line

In order to write better software
Developers should be able to execute requirements as tests

78# gem install syntax to get syntax highlighting
@spork

Feature: DRb Server Integration

To prevent waiting for Rails and other large Ruby applications to load their environments
for each feature run Cucumber ships with a DRb client that can speak to a server which
loads up the environment only once.

Background App with Spork support Spork is a gem that has a DRb server and the scenarios below illustrate how to use it. However, any DRb server that adheres to the protocol that the client expects would work.

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/support/env.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    require 'rubygems'
require 'spork'

Spork.prefork do
  puts "I'm loading all the heavy stuff..."
end

Spork.each_run do
  puts "I'm loading the stuff just for this run..."
end
  3. And a file named "features/sample.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    # language: en
Feature: Sample
  Scenario: this is a test
    Given I am just testing stuff
  4. And a file named "features/essai.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    # language: fr
Fonctionnalit: Essai
  Scenario: ceci est un test
    Soit je teste
  5. And a file named "features/step_definitions/all_your_steps_are_belong_to_us.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Given /^I am just testing stuff$/ do
  # no-op
end

Soit /^je teste$/ do
  # no-op
end

Scenario: Feature Passing with --drb flag

  1. Given I am running spork in the background
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:36
    no such file to load -- spork
    ./features/support/env.rb:115:in `run_spork_in_background'

    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52

Feature: Exception in After Block

In order to use custom assertions at the end of each scenario
As a developer
I want exceptions raised in After blocks to be handled gracefully and reported by the formatters

Background

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Given /^this step does something naughty$/ do x=1
  @naughty = true
end

Given(/^this step works$/) do; end
  3. And a file named "features/support/env.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    class NaughtyScenarioException < Exception; end
After do
  if @naughty
    raise NaughtyScenarioException.new("This scenario has been very very naughty")
  end
end

Scenario: Handle Exception in standard scenario step and carry on

  1. Given a file named "features/naughty_step_in_scenario.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: Sample

  Scenario: Naughty Step
    Given this step does something naughty

  Scenario: Success
    Given this step works
  2. When I run cucumber features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  3. Then it should fail with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Sample

  Scenario: Naughty Step                   # features/naughty_step_in_scenario.feature:3
    Given this step does something naughty # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:1
      This scenario has been very very naughty (NaughtyScenarioException)
      ./features/support/env.rb:4:in `After'

  Scenario: Success       # features/naughty_step_in_scenario.feature:6
    Given this step works # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:5

Failing Scenarios:
cucumber features/naughty_step_in_scenario.feature:3 # Scenario: Naughty Step

2 scenarios (1 failed, 1 passed)
2 steps (2 passed)

Scenario: Handle Exception in scenario outline table row and carry on

  1. Given a file named "features/naughty_step_in_scenario_outline.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: Sample

  Scenario Outline: Naughty Step
    Given this step 

    Examples:
    | Might Work             |
    | works                  |
    | does something naughty |
    | works                  |

  Scenario: Success
    Given this step works
  2. When I run cucumber features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  3. Then it should fail with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Sample

  Scenario Outline: Naughty Step # features/naughty_step_in_scenario_outline.feature:3
    Given this step  # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:5

    Examples: 
      | Might Work             |
      | works                  |
      | does something naughty |
      This scenario has been very very naughty (NaughtyScenarioException)
      ./features/support/env.rb:4:in `After'
      | works                  |

  Scenario: Success       # features/naughty_step_in_scenario_outline.feature:12
    Given this step works # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:5

Failing Scenarios:
cucumber features/naughty_step_in_scenario_outline.feature:3 # Scenario: Naughty Step

4 scenarios (1 failed, 3 passed)
4 steps (4 passed)

  1. Given a file named "features/naughty_step_in_scenario.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: Sample

  Scenario: Naughty Step
    Given this step does something naughty

  Scenario: Success
    Given this step works
  2. When I run cucumber features --format progress

Feature: Exception in AfterStep Block

In order to use custom assertions at the end of each step
As a developer
I want exceptions raised in AfterStep blocks to be handled gracefully and reported by the formatters

Background

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Given /^this step does something naughty$/ do x=1
  @naughty = true
end

Given(/^this step works$/) do; end
  3. And a file named "features/support/env.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    class NaughtyStepException < Exception; end
AfterStep do
  if @naughty
    raise NaughtyStepException.new("This step has been very very naughty")
  end
end

Scenario: Handle Exception in standard scenario step and carry on

  1. Given a file named "features/naughty_step_in_scenario.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28

  Scenario: Naughty Step
    Given this step does something naughty

  Scenario: Success
    Given this step works
  2. When I run cucumber features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  3. Then it should fail with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Sample

  Scenario: Naughty Step                   # features/naughty_step_in_scenario.feature:3
    Given this step does something naughty # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:1
      This step has been very very naughty (NaughtyStepException)
      ./features/support/env.rb:4:in `AfterStep'
      features/naughty_step_in_scenario.feature:4:in `Given this step does something naughty'

  Scenario: Success       # features/naughty_step_in_scenario.feature:6
    Given this step works # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:5

Feature: Exception in Before Block

In order to know with confidence that my before blocks have run OK
As a developer
I want exceptions raised in Before blocks to be handled gracefully and reported by the formatters

Background

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Given(/^this step works$/) do; end
  3. And a file named "features/support/env.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    class SomeSetupException < Exception; end
class BadStepException < Exception; end
Before do
  raise SomeSetupException.new("I cannot even start this scenario")
end

Scenario: Handle Exception in standard scenario step and carry on

  1. Given a file named "features/naughty_step_in_scenario.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: Sample

  Scenario: Run a good step
    Given this step works
  2. When I run cucumber features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  3. Then it should fail with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Sample

  Scenario: Run a good step # features/naughty_step_in_scenario.feature:3
  I cannot even start this scenario (SomeSetupException)
  ./features/support/env.rb:4:in `Before'
    Given this step works   # features/step_definitions/steps.rb:1

Failing Scenarios:
cucumber features/naughty_step_in_scenario.feature:3 # Scenario: Run a good step

1 scenario (1 failed)
1 step (1 skipped)

  Background:
    Given this step works

  Scenario: Run a good step
    Given this step works
  2. When I run cucumber features

Feature: Exclude ruby and feature files from runs

Developers should be able to easily exclude files from cucumber runs
This is a nice feature to have in conjunction with profiles, so you can exclude
certain environment files from certain runs.

Scenario: exclude ruby files

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/support/dont_require_me.rb"
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:24
  3. And a file named "features/step_definitions/fooz.rb"
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:24
  4. And a file named "features/step_definitions/foof.rb"
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:24
  5. And a file named "features/step_definitions/foot.rb"
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:24
  6. And a file named "features/support/require_me.rb"
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:24
  7. When I run cucumber features -q --verbose --exclude features/support/dont --exclude foo[zf]
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  8. Then "features/support/require_me.rb" should be required
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:144
  9. And "features/step_definitions/foot.rb" should be required
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:144
  10. And "features/support/dont_require_me.rb" should not be required
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:140
  11. And "features/step_definitions/foof.rb" should not be required
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:140
  12. And "features/step_definitions/fooz.rb" should not be required
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:140

Feature: --expand option

In order to make it easier to writhe certain editor plugins
and also for some people to understand scenarios, Cucumber
should expand examples in outlines.

Background

  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
  2. And a file named "features/expand_me.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: submit guess

  Background: 
    Given the players' names:
      | maker    | breaker   |
      | Moriarty | Holmes    |

  Scenario Outline: submit guess
    Given the secret code is 
    When I guess 
    Then the mark should be 

  Examples: all colors correct
    | code    | guess   | mark |
    | r g y c | r g y c | bbbb |
    | r g y c | r g c y | bbww |

Scenario: Expand the outline

  1. When I run cucumber -i -q --expand features/expand_me.feature
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  2. Then STDERR should be empty
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:131
  3. And it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: submit guess

  Background: 
    Given the players' names:
      | maker    | breaker |
      | Moriarty | Holmes  |

  Scenario Outline: submit guess
    Given the secret code is 
    When I guess 
    Then the mark should be 

    Examples: all colors correct

      Scenario: | r g y c | r g y c | bbbb |
        Given the secret code is r g y c
        When I guess r g y c
        Then the mark should be bbbb

      Scenario: | r g y c | r g c y | bbww |
        Given the secret code is r g y c
        When I guess r g c y
        Then the mark should be bbww

2 scenarios (2 undefined)
8 steps (8 undefined)
@fails_on_1_9 @rspec2

Feature: HTML formatter

In order to make it easy to read Cucumber results
there should be a HTML formatter with an awesome CSS

Scenario: Everything in fixtures/self_test

  1. When I run cucumber -q --format html --out tmp/a.html features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  2. Then "fixtures/self_test/tmp/a.html" should have the same contents as "features/html_formatter/a.html"
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:111
    expected: "<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC \"-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN\" \"http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd\"><html xmlns =\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml\"><head><meta content=\"text/html;charset=utf-8\"/><title>Cucumber</title><style type=\"text/css\">/* cucumber.css is generated from cucumber.sass */\n/* Regenerate with rake sass */\nbody {\n  font-size: 0px;\n class="val">pystring</span></h3><ol><script>makeYellow('scenario_38');</script><li id='features_undefined_multiline_args_feature_4' class='step undefined'><div class="step_name"><span class="keyword">Given </span><span class="step val">a pystring</span></div><div class="step_file"><span>features/undefined_multiline_args.feature:4</span></div><pre class="val">  example</pre><pre>Given /^a pystring$/ do |string|
   pending # express the regexp above with the code you wish you had
 end</pre></li> <script type="text/javascript">moveProgressBar('97.0');</script></ol></div><div class='scenario'><h3 id="scenario_39"><span class="keyword">Scenario:</span> <span class="val">table</span></h3><ol><script>makeYellow('scenario_39');</script><li id='features_undefined_multiline_args_feature_10' class='step undefined'><div class="step_name"><span class="keyword">Given </span><span class="step val">a table</span></div><div class="step_file"><span>features/undefined_multiline_args.feature:10</span></div><table><tr class='step' id='row_11'><td class="step" id="row_11_0"><div><span class="step param">table</span></div></td></tr> <script type="text/javascript">moveProgressBar('98.2');</script><tr class='step' id='row_12'><td class="step" id="row_12_0"><div><span class="step param">example</span></div></td></tr> <script type="text/javascript">moveProgressBar('98.8');</script></table><pre>Given /^a table$/ do |table|
   # table is a Cucumber::Ast::Table

119# gem install syntax to get syntax highlighting

Feature: JSON output formatter

In order to get results as data
As a developer
Cucumber should be able to output JSON

Background

  1. Given I am in json
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:4

Scenario: one feature, one passing scenario, one failing scenario

  1. And the tmp directory is empty
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:17
  2. When I run cucumber --format json --out tmp/out.json features/one_passing_one_failing.feature
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
  3. Then STDERR should be empty
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:131
  4. And it should fail with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    5.  
  5. And "fixtures/json/tmp/out.json" should match "^\{\"features\":\["
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:107
    6.  
Scenario: one feature, one passing scenario, one failing scenario
     
  1. When I run cucumber --format json_pretty features/one_passing_one_failing.feature
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    2.  
  2. Then STDERR should be empty
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:131

    90
91Then /^it should (fail|pass) with JSON$/ do |success, text|
92  JSON.parse(last_stdout).should == JSON.parse(text)
93  Then("it should #{success}")
94end

Feature: JUnit output formatter
In order for developers to create test reports with ant
Cucumber should be able to output JUnit xml files
Background 
  1. Given I am in junit
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:4
    2.  
  2. And the tmp directory is empty
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:17
    3.  
Scenario: one feature, one passing scenario, one failing scenario
      
  1. When I run cucumber --format junit --out tmp/ features/one_passing_one_failing.feature
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    2.  
  2. Then it should fail with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    3.  
  3. And "fixtures/junit/tmp/TEST-one_passing_one_failing.xml" with junit duration "0.005" should contain
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:100
    




  
    
    
  



    4.  
Scenario: pending steps are simply skipped
      
  1. When I run cucumber --format junit --out tmp/ features/pending.feature
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    2.  
  2. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    3.  
  3. And "fixtures/junit/tmp/TEST-pending.xml" with junit duration "0.009" should contain
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:100
    



    4.  
Scenario: pending step with strict option should fail

    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    2.  
  2. Then it should fail with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    3.  
  3. And "fixtures/junit/tmp/TEST-pending.xml" with junit duration "0.000160" should contain
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:100
    


  
    
    
  



    4.  
Scenario: run all features
      
  1. When I run cucumber --format junit --out tmp/ features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    2.  
  2. Then it should fail with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    3.  
  3. And "fixtures/junit/tmp/TEST-one_passing_one_failing.xml" should exist
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:135

    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:135
    5.  
Scenario: show correct error message if no --out is passed
      
  1. When I run cucumber --format junit features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    2.  
  2. Then STDERR should not match
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:123
    can't convert .* into String \(TypeError\)
    3.  
  3. And STDERR should match
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:119

    4.  
Feature: Language from header
In order to simplify command line and
settings in IDEs, Cucumber should pick
up parser language from a header.
Scenario: LOLCAT
  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
    2.  
  2. And a file named "features/lolcat.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    # language: en-lol
OH HAI: STUFFING
  B4: HUNGRY
  MISHUN: CUKES
    DEN KTHXBAI
    3.  
  3. When I run cucumber -i features/lolcat.feature
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    4.  
  4. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    # language: en-lol
OH HAI: STUFFING

  B4: HUNGRY # features/lolcat.feature:3

  MISHUN: CUKES # features/lolcat.feature:4
    DEN KTHXBAI # features/lolcat.feature:5

1 scenario (1 undefined)
1 step (1 undefined)

    5.  
@needs-many-fonts
Feature: Language help
In order to figure out the keywords to use for a language
I want to be able to get help on the language from the CLI
Scenario: Get help for Portuguese language
  1. When I run cucumber --i18n pt help
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    2.  
  2. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
          | feature          | "Funcionalidade"                           |
      | background       | "Contexto"                                 |
      | scenario         | "Cenrio", "Cenario"                       |
      | scenario_outline | "Esquema do Cenrio", "Esquema do Cenario" |
      | examples         | "Exemplos"                                 |
      | given            | "* ", "Dado "                              |
      | when             | "* ", "Quando "                            |
      | then             | "* ", "Ento ", "Entao "                   |
      | and              | "* ", "E "                                 |
      | but              | "* ", "Mas "                               |
      | given (code)     | "Dado"                                     |
      | when (code)      | "Quando"                                   |
      | then (code)      | "Ento", "Entao"                           |
      | and (code)       | "E"                                        |
      | but (code)       | "Mas"                                      |

    3.  
Scenario: List languages
  1. When I run cucumber --i18n help
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    2.  
  2. Then STDERR should be empty
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:131
    3.  
  3. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
          | ar        | Arabic                 |               |
      | bg        | Bulgarian              |             |
      | ca        | Catalan                | catal               |
      | cs        | Czech                  | esky                |
      | cy-GB     | Welsh                  | Cymraeg              |
      | da        | Danish                 | dansk                |
      | de        | German                 | Deutsch              |
      | en        | English                | English              |
      | en-Scouse | Scouse                 | Scouse               |
      | en-au     | Australian             | Australian           |
      | en-lol    | LOLCAT                 | LOLCAT               |
      | en-pirate | Pirate                 | Pirate               |
      | en-tx     | Texan                  | Texan                |
      | eo        | Esperanto              | Esperanto            |
      | es        | Spanish                | espaol              |

76  Then("it should #{success}")

    6.  
Feature: Profiles
In order to save time and prevent carpal tunnel syndrome
Cucumber users can save and reuse commonly used cucumber flags in a 'cucumber.yml' file.
These named arguments are called profiles and the yml file should be in the root of your project.
Any cucumber argument is valid in a profile.  To see all the available flags type 'cucumber --help'
For more information about profiles please see the wiki:
http://wiki.github.com/aslakhellesoy/cucumber/cucumberyml
Background Basic App
  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
    2.  
  2. And a file named "features/sample.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: Sample
  Scenario: this is a test
    Given I am just testing stuff
    3.  
  3. And a file named "features/support/env.rb"
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:24
    4.  
  4. And a file named "features/support/super_env.rb"
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:24
    5.  
  5. And the following profiles are defined:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:32
    default: features/sample.feature --require features/support/env.rb -v
super: features/sample.feature --require features/support/super_env.rb -v
    6.  
Scenario: Explicitly defining a profile to run
         
  1. When I run cucumber features/sample.feature --profile super
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    2.  
  2. Then the output should contain
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:79
    Using the super profile...
    3.  
  3. And exactly these files should be loaded: features/support/super_env.rb
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:148
    4.  
Scenario: Explicitly defining a profile defined in an ERB formatted file
         
  1. Given the following profiles are defined:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:32
    <% requires = "--require features/support/super_env.rb" %>
super: <%= "features/sample.feature #{requires} -v" %>
    2.  
  2. When I run cucumber features/sample.feature --profile super
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    3.  
  3. Then the output should contain
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:79
    Using the super profile...
    4.  
  4. And exactly these files should be loaded: features/support/super_env.rb
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:148
    5.  
Scenario: Defining multiple profiles to run
         
  1. When I run cucumber features/sample.feature --profile default --profile super
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    2.  
  2. Then the output should contain
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:79
    Using the default and super profiles...
    3.  
  3. And exactly these files should be loaded: features/support/env.rb, features/support/super_env.rb
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:148
    4.  
Scenario: Arguments passed in but no profile specified
         
  1. When I run cucumber -v
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    2.  
  2. Then the default profile should be used
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:156
    3.  
  3. And exactly these files should be loaded: features/support/env.rb
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:148
    4.

    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    2.  
  2. Then STDERR should be
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:127
    Could not find profile: 'foo'

Defined profiles in cucumber.yml:
  * default
  * super

Scenario: Overriding the profile's formatter
You will most likely want to define a formatter in your default formatter.
However, you often want to run your features with a different formatter
yet still use the other the other arguments in the profile. Cucumber will
allow you to do this by giving precedence to the formatter specified on the
command line and override the one in the profile.
         
  1. Given the following profiles are defined:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:32
    default: features/sample.feature --require features/support/env.rb -v --format profile
    2.  
  2. When I run cucumber features --format pretty
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    3.  
  3. And the output should contain
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:79
    Feature: Sample
    4.  
Scenario Outline: Showing profiles when listing failing scenarios
  1. Given a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Given /^I am just testing stuff$/ do
  raise 'BANG'
end
    2.  
  2. When I run cucumber -q -p super -p default -f <format> features/sample.feature --require features/step_definitions/steps.rb
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    3.  
  3. Then it should fail
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:64
    4.  
  4. And the output should contain
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:79
    cucumber -p super features/sample.feature:2 # Scenario: this is a test
    5.

    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:32

require 'cucumber/rake/task'

  t.profile = "foo"
end

Feature: Cucumber command line
In order to find out what step definitions need to be implemented
Developers should always see what step definition is missing
Scenario: Get info at arbitrary levels of nesting

    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    2.  
  2. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Calling undefined step

  Scenario: Call directly                                # features/call_undefined_step_from_step_def.feature:3
    Given a step definition that calls an undefined step # features/step_definitions/sample_steps.rb:19
      Undefined step: "this does not exist" (Cucumber::Undefined)
      ./features/step_definitions/sample_steps.rb:19:in `/^a step definition that calls an undefined step$/'
      features/call_undefined_step_from_step_def.feature:4:in `Given a step definition that calls an undefined step'

  Scenario: Call via another                                         # features/call_undefined_step_from_step_def.feature:6

      Undefined step: "this does not exist" (Cucumber::Undefined)
      ./features/step_definitions/sample_steps.rb:19:in `/^a step definition that calls an undefined step$/'
      features/call_undefined_step_from_step_def.feature:7:in `Given call step "a step definition that calls an undefined step"'

2 scenarios (2 undefined)
2 steps (2 undefined)

You can implement step definitions for undefined steps with these snippets:

Given /^this does not exist$/ do
  pending # express the regexp above with the code you wish you had
end

You can implement step definitions for undefined steps with these snippets:

Given /^I have some cukes$/ do
  pending # express the regexp above with the code you wish you had
end

If you want snippets in a different programming language, just make sure a file
with the appropriate file extension exists where cucumber looks for step definitions.

Feature: Table diffing
In order to more easily compare data in tables
step definition writers should be able to diff
a table with expected data and see the diff inline
Scenario: Extra row
  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
    2.  
  2. And a file named "features/tables.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: Tables
  Scenario: Extra row
    Then the table should be:
      | x | y |
      | a | b |
    3.  
  3. And a file named "features/step_definitions/table_steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Then /the table should be:/ do |expected| x=1
  expected.diff!(table(%{
    | x | y | 
    | a | c |
  }))
end
    4.  
  4. When I run cucumber -i features/tables.feature
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    5.  
  5. Then it should fail with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Tables

  Scenario: Extra row         # features/tables.feature:2
    Then the table should be: # features/step_definitions/table_steps.rb:1
      | x | y |
      | a | b |
      | a | c |
      Tables were not identical (Cucumber::Ast::Table::Different)
      ./features/step_definitions/table_steps.rb:2:in `/the table should be:/'
      features/tables.feature:3:in `Then the table should be:'

Scenario: Mapping table shouldn't change output
  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
    2.

    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28

  Scenario: S
    Given a table:
      | who   |
      | aslak |
    3.  
  3. And a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Given(/a table:/) { |table| table.map_headers!(/who/i => 'Who')
  table.map_column!('Who') { |who| "Cuke" }
  table.hashes[0]['Who'] = "Joe"
  table.hashes.should == [{"Who"=>"Joe"}]
}

Feature: transform
In order to maintain modularity within step definitions
As a step definition editor
I want to register a regex to capture and tranform step definition arguments.
Background 
  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
    2.  
  2. And a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Then /^I should transform ('\d+' to an Integer)$/ do |integer|
  integer.should be_kind_of(Integer)
end

Then /^I should transform ('\w+' to a Symbol)$/ do |symbol|
  symbol.should be_kind_of(Symbol)
end

Then /^I should transform ('\d+' to a Float)$/ do |float|
  float.should be_kind_of(Float)
end

Then /^I should transform ('\w+' to an Array)$/ do |array|
  array.should be_kind_of(Array)
end

Then /^I should transform ('\w+' to Nil)$/ do |string|
  string.should be_nil
end

Then /^I should not transform ('\d+') to an Integer$/ do |string|
  string.should be_kind_of(String)
end

Then /^I should transform ((?:nothing|'\d+') to an optional Integer)$/ do |integer|
  integer.should be_nil
end
    3.  
  3. And a file named "features/support/env.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Transform /^'\d+' to an Integer$/ do |step_arg|
  /'(\d+)' to an Integer/.match(step_arg).captures[0].to_i
end

Transform /^(?:nothing|'(\d+)') to an optional Integer$/ do |str|
  str ? str.to_i : nil
end

Transform /^'(\d+)' to a Float$/ do |integer_string|
  Transform("'#{integer_string}' to an Integer").to_f
end

Transform(/^('\w+') to Nil$/) {|str| nil }

Transform(/^('\w+') to a Symbol$/) {|str| str.to_sym }

module MyHelpers
  def fetch_array
    @array
  end
end

World(MyHelpers)

Before do
  @array = []
end

Transform(/^('\w+') to an Array$/) {|str| fetch_array }
    4.  
Scenario: run a specific scenario with a registered transform
       
  1. Given a file named "features/transform_sample.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: Step argument transformations

  Scenario: transform with matches
    Then I should transform '10' to an Integer

  Scenario: transform with matches that capture
    Then I should transform 'abc' to a Symbol

  Scenario: transform with matches that reuse transforms
    Then I should transform '10' to a Float

  Scenario: transform with matches that use current world
    Then I should transform 'abc' to an Array

  Scenario: transform with matches that return nil
    Then I should transform 'nil' to Nil

  Scenario: transform without matches
    Then I should not transform '10' to an Integer

  Scenario: transform with optional arguments not given
    Then I should transform nothing to an optional Integer
    2.  
  2. When I run cucumber --backtrace -s features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    3.  
  3. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Step argument transformations

  Scenario: transform with matches
    Then I should transform '10' to an Integer

  Scenario: transform with matches that capture
    Then I should transform 'abc' to a Symbol

  Scenario: transform with matches that reuse transforms
    Then I should transform '10' to a Float

  Scenario: transform with matches that use current world
    Then I should transform 'abc' to an Array

  Scenario: transform with matches that return nil
    Then I should transform 'nil' to Nil

  Scenario: transform without matches
    Then I should not transform '10' to an Integer

  Scenario: transform with optional arguments not given
    Then I should transform nothing to an optional Integer

7 scenarios (7 passed)
7 steps (7 passed)

    4.  
Scenario: run a table scenario with an unrelated registered transform

    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: Step argument transformations

  Scenario: A table
    Then I should check the following table:
      | letter | letter_plus_a |
      |      r |            ra |
      |      m |            ma |
      |      p |            pa |
    2.  
  2. And a file named "features/support/table.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Transform /^table:number,number_plus_a$/ do |table|
  :not_what_you_were_expecting
end

Then "I should check the following table:" do |table|
  table.hashes.each do |hash|
    hash['letter_plus_a'].should == (hash['letter'] + 'a')
  end
end

  3. When I run cucumber -s features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    4.

    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Step argument transformations

  Scenario: A table
    Then I should check the following table:
      | letter | letter_plus_a |
      | r      | ra            |
      | m      | ma            |
      | p      | pa            |

Scenario: run a table scenario with an related registered transform not using table

    Feature: Step argument transformations

  Scenario: A table
    Then I should check the following table:
      | letter | letter_plus_a |
      |      r |            ra |
      |      m |            ma |
      |      p |            pa |

  1

  columns.should == 1

      | m      | ma            |
      | p      | pa            |

    5.  
Scenario: run a table scenario with an related registered transform using table
       
  1. Given a file named "features/transform_sample.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: Step argument transformations

  Scenario: A table
    Then I should check the following table:
      | letter | letter_plus_a |
      |      r |            ra |
      |      m |            ma |
      |      p |            pa |
    2.  
  2. And a file named "features/support/table.rb" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Transform /^table:letter,letter_plus_a$/ do |table|
  table.rows.map { |row| row.join(',') }
end

Then "I should check the following table:" do |rows_in_table|
  rows_in_table.should == ['r,ra','m,ma','p,pa']
end
    3.  
  3. When I run cucumber -b -s features
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    4.  
  4. Then it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: Step argument transformations

  Scenario: A table
    Then I should check the following table:
      | letter | letter_plus_a |
      | r      | ra            |
      | m      | ma            |
      | p      | pa            |

1 scenario (1 passed)
1 step (1 passed)

    5.  
Feature: Unicode in tables
In order to please the whole world,
unicode characters in tables should be
properly aligned
Scenario: All sorts of weird stuff
  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
    2.  
  2. And a file named "features/unicode.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: Featuring unicode

  Scenario: So what, whatever
    Given passing
      | Brno | abc |
      | Bruno |  |
    3.

43 scenarios (32 skipped, 10 undefined, 1 passed)
131 steps (117 skipped, 14 undefined)

    4.  
@wire
Feature: Wire Protocol
In order to be allow Cucumber to touch my app in intimate places
As a developer on platform which doesn't support Ruby
I want a low-level protocol which Cucumber can use to run steps within my app
#
# Cucumber's wire protocol is an implementation of Cucumber's internal
# 'programming language' abstraction, and allows step definitions to be
# implemented and invoked on any platform.
#
# Communication is over a TCP socket, which Cucumber connects to when it finds
# a definition file with the .wire extension in the step_definitions folder
# (or other load path).
#
# Cucumber sends the following request messages out over the wire:
#
#   * step_matches   : this is used to find out whether the wire server has a
#                      definition for a given step
#   * invoke         : this is used to ask for a step definition to be invoked
#   * begin_scenario : signals that cucumber is about to execute a scenario
#   * end_scenario   : signals that cucumber has finished executing a scenario
#   * snippet_text   : requests a snippet for an undefined step
#
# Every message supports two standard responses:
#   * success        : which expects different arguments (sometimes none at
#                      all) depending on the request.
#   * fail           : causes a Cucumber::WireSupport::WireException to be
#                      raised.
#
# Some messages support more responses - see below for details.
#
# A WirePacket flowing in either direction is formatted as a JSON-encoded
# string, with a newline character signalling the end of a packet. See the
# specs for Cucumber::WireSupport::WirePacket for more details.
#
# These messages are described in detail below, with examples.
#
Background 
  1. Given a standard Cucumber project directory structure
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:8
    2.  
  2. And a file named "features/wired.feature" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    Feature: High strung
  Scenario: Wired
    Given we're all wired

    3.  
  3. And a file named "features/step_definitions/some_remote_place.wire" with:
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:28
    host: localhost
port: 54321

    4.  
#
# # Request: 'step_matches'
#
# When the features have been parsed, Cucumber will send a step_matches
# message to ask the wire server if it can match a step name. This happens for
# each of the steps in each of the features.
#
# The wire server replies with an array of StepMatch objects.
Scenario: Dry run finds no step match
       
  1. Given there is a wire server running on port 54321 which understands the following protocol:
    features/step_definitions/wire_steps.rb:1
    request
    response
     
    ["step_matches",{"name_to_match":"we're all wired"}]
    ["success",[]]
     
    2.  
  2. When I run cucumber --dry-run --no-snippets -f progress
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    3.  
  3. And it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    U

1 scenario (1 undefined)
1 step (1 undefined)

    4.  
# When each StepMatch is returned, it contains the following data:
#   * id   - identifier for the step definition to be used later when if it
#            needs to be invoked. The identifier can be any string value and
#            is simply used for the wire server's own reference.
#   * args - any argument values as captured by the wire end's own regular
#            expression (or other argument matching) process.
Scenario: Dry run finds a step match
       
  1. Given there is a wire server running on port 54321 which understands the following protocol:
    features/step_definitions/wire_steps.rb:1
    request
    response
     
    ["step_matches",{"name_to_match":"we're all wired"}]
    ["success",[{"id":"1", "args":[]}]]
     
    2.  
  2. When I run cucumber --dry-run -f progress
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    3.  
  3. And it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    -

1 scenario (1 skipped)
1 step (1 skipped)

    4.  
# Optionally, the StepMatch can also contain a source reference, and a native
# regexp string which will be used by some formatters.
Scenario: Step matches returns details about the remote step definition
       
  1. Given there is a wire server running on port 54321 which understands the following protocol:
    features/step_definitions/wire_steps.rb:1
    request
    response
     
    ["step_matches",{"name_to_match":"we're all wired"}]
    ["success",[{"id":"1", "args":[], "source":"MyApp.MyClass:123", "regexp":"we.*"}]]
     
    2.  
  2. When I run cucumber -f stepdefs --dry-run
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    3.  
  3. Then STDERR should be empty
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:131
    4.  
  4. And it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    -

we.*   # MyApp.MyClass:123

1 scenario (1 skipped)
1 step (1 skipped)

    5.  
#
# # Request: 'invoke'
#
# Assuming a StepMatch was returned for a given step name, when it's time to
# invoke that step definition, Cucumber will send an invoke message.
#
# The invoke message contains the ID of the step definition, as returned by
# the wire server in response to the the step_matches call, along with the
# arguments that were parsed from the step name during the same step_matches
# call.
#
# The wire server will normally[1] reply one of the following:
#   * success
#   * fail
#   * pending : optionally takes a message argument
#
# [1] This isn't the whole story: see also wire_protocol_table_diffing.feature
#
# ## Pending Steps
#
Scenario: Invoke a step definition which is pending
       
  1. Given there is a wire server running on port 54321 which understands the following protocol:
    features/step_definitions/wire_steps.rb:1
    request
    response
     
    ["step_matches",{"name_to_match":"we're all wired"}]
    ["success",[{"id":"1", "args":[]}]]
     
    ["begin_scenario"]
    ["success"]
     
    ["invoke",{"id":"1","args":[]}]
    ["pending", "I'll do it later"]
     
    ["end_scenario"]
    ["success"]
     
    2.  
  2. When I run cucumber -f pretty -q
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52
    3.  
  3. And it should pass with
    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
    Feature: High strung

  Scenario: Wired
    Given we're all wired
      I'll do it later (Cucumber::Pending)
      features/wired.feature:3:in `Given we're all wired'

1 scenario (1 pending)
1 step (1 pending)

    4.  
# ## Passing Steps
#
Scenario: Invoke a step definition which passes
       
  1. Given there is a wire server running on port 54321 which understands the following protocol:
    features/step_definitions/wire_steps.rb:1
    request
    response
     
    ["step_matches",{"name_to_match":"we're all wired"}]
    ["success",[{"id":"1", "args":[]}]]
     
    ["begin_scenario"]
    ["success"]
     
    ["invoke",{"id":"1","args":[]}]
    ["success"]
     
    ["end_scenario"]
    ["success"]
     
    2.

    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:52

    features/step_definitions/cucumber_steps.rb:74
